summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment against MaineGeneral Health, Inc., a health insurance company, and Melissa True, an employee of MaineGeneral, for violating the federal securities laws.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Orlando, Florida, alleges that, in August 2014, Melissa True entered into a "Gestational Carrier Agreement" with intended parents, Anxo Cereijo Roibas and Szczepan Wojciech, in which she agreed to submit claims for all pregnancy-related medical expenses, including expenses related to a surrogate mother's pregnancy and childbirth.  According to the complaint, True was informed on that call that there was no exclusion, but the expenses of a pregnancy that results when a plan participant serves as a surrogate were not covered by the Plan.  In addition, the complaint alleges that True initially received benefits for some of her pregnancy expenses only to find out later that her claims were denied because she was not an active member on the date that she called.  As alleged in the SEC's Complaint, the Defendants violated the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and the broker-dealer registration provision of Section 15(b)(5) of Exchange Act Rule 15b2-1 thereunder.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the Defendants' complaint, the defendants have consented to the entry of judgments that permanently enjoin them from violating the charged provisions of the Exchange Act, and order them to pay disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and civil penalties in amounts to be determined by the court upon motion by the parties.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 554 (D.R.I. 2014).  In a related administrative proceeding, the SEC announced that it had obtained an emergency court order freezing the assets of Maine General Health, and that the court would consider the merits of the emergency relief action brought by the SEC.  On May 4, 2017, the court granted a temporary restraining order and ordered MaineGeneral to comply with the court's order.  A hearing scheduled for June 21, 2018, was scheduled for 7:30 p.m. Eastern.  To learn more about how to spot inconsistencies in the ERISA books and procedures, see Press Release No: 531 F.3d 84, 94 (1st Cir. 2008).  The case was supervised by Kelly L. Gibson, Chief of the Boston Regional Office.  An SEC examination that led to the investigation of the matter was conducted by John R. Rymas of the Market Abuse Unit in the Philadelphia Regional Office, including
